introduction.p: Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals. Check each antiderivative that you find by differentiating.

solution.p: Using u = t and dv = e^{-t} dt, we obtain du = dt and v = -e^{-t}. So \int t e^{-t} dt \amp = -te^{-t} + \int e^{-t} dt\amp = -te^{-t} - e^{-t} + c We check using differentiation as follows: \frac{d}{dt} \left( -te^{-t} - e^{-t} + c \right) \amp = \left( t e^{-t} - e^{-t} \right) + e^{-t}\amp = te^{-t}

Using u = 4x and dv = \sin(3x) dx, we obtain du = 4 dx and v = -\dfrac{1}{3} \cos(3x). So \int 4x \sin(3x) dx \amp = -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \dfrac{4}{3} \int \cos(3x) dx\amp = -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \frac{4}{9} \sin(3x) + c We check using differentiation as follows: \frac{d}{dx} \left( -\dfrac{4}{3} x \cos(3x) + \frac{4}{9} \sin(3x) + c \right) \amp = \left( 4x \sin(3x) - \frac{4}{3} \cos(3x) \right) + \frac{4}{3} \cos(3x)\amp = 4x \sin(3x)

Using u = z and dv = \sec^2(z) dz, we obtain du = dz and v = \tan(z). So \int z \sec^2(z) dz \amp = z \tan(z) - \int \tan(z) dz\amp = z \tan(z) + \ln |\cos(z)| + c We check using differentiation as follows: \frac{d}{dz} \left( z \tan(z) + \ln (\cos(z)) + c \right) \amp = z\sec^2(z) + \tan(z) - \frac{\sin(z)}{\cos(z)}\amp = z\sec^2(z) + \tan(z) - \tan(z)\amp = z \sec^2(z)

hint.p: Note that \ln(x) \, dx has a simple derivative to work with.

solution.p: Using u = \ln(x) and dv = x dx, we obtain du = \dfrac{1}{x} dx and v = \dfrac{1}{2}x^2. So \int x\ln(x) dx \amp = \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{2} \int x dx\amp = \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{4}x^2 + c We check using differentiation as follows: \frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{1}{2}x^2 \ln(x) - \frac{1}{4}x^2 + c \right) \amp = \frac{1}{2}x + x \ln(x) - \frac{1}{2} x\amp = x \ln(x)
